title: Letter: It's hardly surprising New Yorkers shun the subway
text:
I read with admiration, and hopeless longing, of Mayor Eric Adams' plea for Jamie Dimon, the JPMorgan chief executive, to take the subway.

As a native New Yorker, I have always found it mystifying how the city's denizens, grand and humble alike, have resigned themselves to a state of public transit so incommensurate with the city's grandeur.

To use the (once-disparaging) epithet “third world” to describe the condition of our infrastructure today would be an insult to developing nations.

A wise man — a Latin American economist — once remarked that a civilised country is not a place where the poor have cars, but rather one where the rich use public transportation. Bankers as well-travelled as Dimon surely know what it's like to spend time in places where this observation applies (certainly as a rule in cities such as Zurich and Vienna, and perhaps to a lesser degree, London.)

If the goal is indeed to get people back to work, physically, in New York the question is now whether Messrs. Adams and Dimon — as well as the rest of the city's stakeholders — believe we deserve to live in a civilised place too.

David Kaufman
Zurich, Switzerland
